vehicles.title: New Glenn
vehicles.description: New Glenn is a two-stage rocket with a diameter of 7 m (23 ft). Its first stage will be powered by seven BE-4 engines that use liquid methane / liquid oxygen as propellants and is designed to be reusable for up to 25 missions. New Glenn is capable of carrying people and payloads to Earth orbit and beyond.
vehicles.alt: A digital rendering of Blue Origin's New Glenn

vehicles.title: Starship
vehicles.description: The Starship spacecraft and Super Heavy rocket, which are collectively known as Starship, form a reusable transport system created by SpaceX that can transport both crew and cargo to Earth's orbit, the Moon, Mars, and other destinations. Starship is anticipated to be the most potent launch vehicle ever designed, capable of transporting up to 150 metric tonnes of reusable cargo to Earth's orbit and up to 250 metric tonnes of expendable cargo.
vehicles.alt: A digital rendering of SpaceX's Starship flying through the atmosphere

vehicles.title: Falcon 9
vehicles.description: The Falcon 9 rocket, created and produced by SpaceX, is a two-stage vehicle that is intended to transport individuals into Earth's orbit and beyond in a dependable and secure manner. This rocket is the first reusable rocket in the world capable of orbiting the Earth. The reuse of the Falcon 9 rocket's most costly components helps to reduce the cost of space access.
vehicles.alt: A picture of SpaceX's FalconX rocket launching into space

vehicles.title: Soyuz MS
vehicles.description: The Soyuz MS is a spacecraft designed for crewed spaceflight operations and cargo transport to the International Space Station. It is a modernized version of the Soyuz family of spacecraft and features upgrades and improvements, such as the ability to carry up to three crew members and remain in space for up to 200 days. The Soyuz MS consists of three modules and is launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan. Its reliability and safety have made it one of the most widely used spacecraft in spaceflight history.
vehicles.alt: A picture of the Soyuz MS rocket launching into space
